MainPageText:
You will be reading six different texts with different background and forground colours, and then asked some questions about said texts.
Please SKIM read through these texts, and then answer all the questions.
After all of the samples and questions are done, you will be asked a number of questions about how much you liked each sample colour combination. Please make sure to answer this as well.

0.Name: The Count of Monte Cristo by Alexander Dumas (1845)
0.SampleText: The pinnacle of prison escape novels, Dumas’ novel is a tale of suffering and retribution. The eponymous count escapes his prison confines and retrieves a hoard of treasure, setting in motion his justified revenge. Our sympathies always remain with the innocent Edmond Dantès, and we relish every second of his reprisal.

0.QuestionString: Who is the author of this book?

1.QuestionString: What is the count trying to accomplish?

QuestionItems.0: Become the Count of Monte Cristo

2.QuestionString: What is this novel described as?

QuestionItems.0: The pinnacle of all murder mysteries
QuestionItems.1: The principle of all prison escape novels
QuestionItems.2: The pinnacle of all prison escape novels

1.Name: The Spy who came in from the Cold by John LeCarre (1963)
1.SampleText: Le Carré’s breakthrough novel makes an appearance in my book, noting that it was written by the spy master in the very year I follow in Berlin (1962). The Berlin Wall had just gone up and escapes in any and all forms were attempted daily. The book concludes with the memorable scene atop the Wall as hero Alec Leamas attempts to help his lover Liz Gold over the barrier – but she falls backs as gunfire erupts and instead of jumping to safety in the west he leaps back to the east and certain death.

0.QuestionString: When and where is this book set?

QuestionItems.0: Berlin, 1962, just after the Berlin wall was built

1.QuestionString: What does the protagonist do at the end of the book?

QuestionItems.0: He saves his lover and manges to climb over the wall
QuestionItems.1: He attempts to save his lover but ultimatly fails and jumps back over the wall to certain death
QuestionItems.2: He attempts to save his lover but ultimatly fails and climbs over the wall to safety

2.QuestionString: What is the author described as?

0.Name: A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens (1859)
0.SampleText: Yes, we may remember Madame LaFarge and the closing execution scene, but the plot actually pivots on the Sidney Carton/Charles Darnay prison switcheroo. And the memorable line tied to the escape: “It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.”

0.QuestionString: What is the most memorable line of the book?

QuestionItems.0: May the force be with you
QuestionItems.1: All work and no pay make Jack a dull boy
QuestionItems.2: It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.

1.QuestionString: Who does the plot revolve around?

1.Name: Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption by Stephen King (1982)
1.SampleText: There is no character we root for in this oddly titled novella more than Andy Dufresne. Andy’s resolution is idyllic to say the least, as his unbelievably well-organised escape – from tunnelling through the prison wall to the black rock hiding a crucial letter – works perfectly in his favour, leaving the reader with a smug sense of satisfaction as the duped prison warden is left scratching his head.

0.QuestionString: What is the name of the character that readers root for the most

1.QuestionString: How did the protagonist escape from prison?

QuestionItems.0: He disguised himself as a janitor

2.QuestionString: What do most readers fell at the end of the book?

QuestionItems.0: Smug satisfaction at how confused the duped warden is
QuestionItems.2: Sad for the main character because he was caught in the end

0.Name: Room by Emma Donoghue (2010)
0.SampleText: Donoghue’s story of a young boy called Jack and his resourceful ma, held captive and forced to exist solely in “Room”, is a very different kind of escape novel. Told entirely from the innocent point of view of Jack, who has no experience of the outside world, the escape itself is a gruelling moment as we desperately hope that this confused and vulnerable child will be able to save himself and his mother. But what really makes this novel so distinct is its depiction of the aftermath; there is no immediate fist-in-the-air triumph, but a long and difficult struggle to return to normality after a traumatic event.

0.QuestionString: From whose point of view is this story told?

QuestionItems.2: The person whose holding Jack and his mother prisoner

1.QuestionString: What is the aftermath of the escape?

QuestionItems.1: A long and difficult struggle to return to normality after a traumatic event
QuestionItems.2: The boy and his mother are recaptured and put back in the “Room”

2.QuestionString: What is considered to be the most gruelling moment in the book?

1.Name: Follow the Rabbit-Proof Fence by Doris Pilkington (1992)
1.SampleText: Having to escape an institution that has been sanctioned by the government to support prejudicial and extremist philosophies is not unusual in literature. After all, history has given us many real-life events to draw upon. But Pilkington’s novel, focusing on the “stolen generation” of Indigenous Australian children removed from their families by government agencies, is particularly unsettling because it explores a period of history not often discussed and because the escapees are children.

1.QuestionString: What did the australian government do to the indigenous Australians?

QuestionItems.0: They rounded them up and put them in camps
QuestionItems.1: They removed children from families by using government agencies

2.QuestionString: Why is this novel considered unsettling?

QuestionItems.0: It’s set in a period of history not often discussed and because the escapee are children
QuestionItems.1: It’s set in a period of history which is well known and because the escapee are teens
QuestionItems.2: It’s set in a period of history not often discussed and because the escapee are adults

0.QuestionString: On a scale of 1 to 6, how much did you like the black on white combination? (1 being hated and 6 being loved)

1.QuestionString: On a scale of 1 to 6, how much did you like the light green on dark green combination? (1 being hated and 6 being loved)

2.QuestionString: On a scale of 1 to 6, how much did you like the red on black combination? (1 being hated and 6 being loved)
